page.title: 14Flora of the Railway Line.
page.content: The railway line from Saxmundham to Aldeburgh has long-since stopped having travelling passengers. Today the C.E.G.B. use the existing line from the Sizewell Road crossing for transporting very heavy loads to and from the power station at Sizewell. The track beyond has been removed and is now over-grown with weeds and flowers. However, in a recent study, sixty different flowers and grasses were found to be growing in this area. Beside the path can be found gorse, nettles, hawthorn, elder, bushes, bramble and bracken. Many of the flowers like stone crop, storks bill, bird foot, trefoil, vetch and lady's bedstraw grow on the bare track, while toadflax, greates knapweed, field scabious, carline thistle, musk thistle, ragwort, ribwort plaintain, honey suckle and many grasses grow on the bankside.
